entry.title: Migrating SAP PI/PO XI Proxy scenarios to Integration Suite ‚Äì Key considerations and recommendations
entry.content:
With the recent features in SAP Integration Suite‚Äîsuch as the ability to migrate Service Interfaces from SAP PI/PO to Cloud Integration and the introduction of the pipeline concept, the topic of migrating XI Proxies to Integration Suite has gained fresh significance. If you‚Äôve been waiting for the right moment to move your proxy-based integrations, this might just be it. The following sections outline key considerations and practical recommendations for a smooth and future-ready transition.

A) Modernize While You Migrate

While SAP supports the migration of legacy protocols such as Proxy, helping customers preserve their existing investments, it‚Äôs also a good time to consider modernization. Move away from older or proprietary interfaces toward modern, cloud-native, and interoperable options like SOAP or OData services to ensure long-term stability and easier evolution of your integration landscape.

B) Leverage SAP provided Accelerators

Before you start rebuilding interfaces from scratch, explore what SAP already provides out-of-the-box, from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

  • Prepackaged Integration Content: SAP Integration Suite pre-built content can significantly accelerate migration by making use of pre-delivered integration flows, script collections, etc., spanning across key end-to-end business processes, cutting across your SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Standard APIs and Events: Consume standard APIs and business events available for your SAP S/4HANA edition to avoid / reduce customization and thus keep the core clean.

C) Migrating ESR Proxy Objects to Integration Suite

In the ECC ‚Äì PI/PO landscape, the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR) served as the central design-time hub for maintaining and versioning proxy schemas and interface definitions. This enabled the well-established ‚Äúoutside-in‚Äù development model, where integration developers first defined the structure in middleware via Data type, Message type and Service Interface, after which ABAPers implemented the Proxy class/method in the backend.

When SAP Integration Suite was first introduced, it lacked an ESR-equivalent capability to host and manage proxy schemas. Consequently, one option for customers was to keep their PI/PO ESR systems running to maintain these schemas, regenerate proxies in S/4HANA, and then use Integration Suite iflows for execution.

Additionally, SAP also introduced the Metadata Repository in S/4HANA, allowing schemas to be maintained directly within the backend (via the transaction SPXNMIG)‚Äîremoving the dependency on ESR. However, this represented a shift from the earlier outside-in model to a more backend-driven (‚Äúinside-out‚Äù) approach.

With the new feature released in Q3 2025 allowing migration of Service Interface objects from ESR to Integration Suite, it‚Äôs now possible to manage proxy schemas directly within Integration Suite‚Äîjust as you did in PI/PO. This advancement removes the need to depend on S/4HANA‚Äôs metadata repository or continue operating ESR purely for schema governance. It reintroduces the familiar outside-in development model, allowing interface definitions to remain in the integration layer.

Please also read this blog post, for additional details on proxy generation based on Service Interface migrated to Integration Suite.

This step of migrating your Service Interface object from SAP PI/PO is optional, and you need it only if you want to continue maintaining or modifying the proxy schema in the future. Otherwise, you can proceed directly with migrating runtime artifacts via the migration tooling guided wizard (discussed in the next section below).

D) Migrating Proxy-Based Scenarios (Deployable Components)

While we focused earlier on moving design-time definitions such as Service Interfaces (SI) and Message Types (MT), this step deals with the deployable components that enable actual message processing in Integration Suite.

To clarify the distinction ‚Äî the Service Interface you migrated in the previous step is not deployed in the Integration Suite tenant. It remains as a repository artifact, referenced by the backend system via SPROXY for proxy generation and linkage at runtime. Its purpose ends there. If, at any point in the future, you need to enhance or extend the schema, you would do so by editing the underlying Message Type that the Service Interface references.

In this step, we focus on migrating the ICO objects as iflows ‚Äî the deployable components responsible for message execution during runtime.

You can use the migration tooling to convert your existing XI proxy-based configurations into equivalent iflows. Depending on your Migration strategy, you can choose between standard approach or pipeline approach. The pipeline approach offers several operational benefits, such as reduced number of JMS queues, artifact reuse, simplified operations with clearly separated error queues, sophisticated restart mechanisms and Exactly Once message processing ‚Äì to name a few. Especially for Proxy-based scenarios, the pipeline concept helps in Reliable message processing, decoupling, common entry point for inbound scenarios (as described in the next section). Given these advantages, we recommend that you consider and apply the pipeline concept to migrate your Proxy based scenarios to Integration Suite. Read more about the Pipeline concept in this blog post.

E) Establishing a Common Entry Point

Establish a common entry point for all inbound XI Proxy messages either by modelling your own generic inbound iflow for XI, or leveraging the out-of-the-box generic XI inbound iflow that comes as part of the pipeline concept. The common entry point mirrors the Generic XI Sender Channel setup you may recall from SAP PI/PO. The generic XI inbound iflow, shipped as part of the generic pipeline package is impressively versatile‚Äîit can handle all QoS (Exactly Once, Exactly Once in Order, and Best Effort) without additional development or configuration effort. That‚Äôs yet another strong reason to choose the pipeline approach.

F) Configuring a Single Destination

As a corollary of setting up a common entry-point iflow, only one HTTP destination is required from your SAP S/4HANA system‚Äîpointing to this generic inbound iflow. This simplifies connectivity setup and minimizes administrative overhead.

G) Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues and Federated Landscape Design in Pipeline-Based Proxy Migrations

In this section, we‚Äôll discuss two aspects that could come into play at the intersection of XI Proxy migration and the pipeline concept in SAP Integration Suite:

1) Defining Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues
In classic SAP PI/PO, message monitoring could be conveniently filtered by Communication Component, giving operations team a clear view of message traffic per backend system. While Integration Suite does not mirror this behaviour directly, a similar outcome can be achieved within the pipeline setup by defining sender- or receiver-specific JMS queues. This approach allows message segregation per system, targeted retries, and operational isolation without interfering with other integrations. More details on configuring sender / receiver specific JMS queues for pipeline can be found in this Help portal page.

2) setting up separate pipelines for federated landscapes
Many enterprises historically operated multiple ABAP backends‚Äîsuch as Finance, SRM, or CRM‚Äîsupported by distinct PI/PO systems aligned by Line of Business (LoB) or regional boundaries. As these organizations move toward Integration Suite modernization and consolidate middleware into a single tenant, it remains important to retain autonomy and governance separation across business domains.

The pipeline approach enables this by allowing you to replicate the standard pipeline package into individual design workspaces‚Äîone per LoB or region‚Äîsupported by consistent artifact naming conventions and Access Policies that control visibility and ownership. This setup helps balance consolidation with distributed control, ensuring each domain can manage its proxy-based integration flows independently.
With this rationale in mind, SAP has published the New Integration Packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

This model preserves the federated operating style of large enterprises while streamlining governance, monitoring, and operations within a single, cloud-native Integration Suite tenant.

While the considerations in this section‚Äîqueue separation and federated pipelines‚Äîare applicable to other interface types and protocols as well, they are highlighted here because proxy-based interfaces typically form a significant portion of many organizations‚Äô legacy landscape. Addressing these design aspects as part of proxy migration ensures that modernization efforts not only move interfaces to the cloud but also align with scalable, operationally sustainable integration practices suited for the long term.

Most PI/PO systems carry a large footprint of Proxy interfaces. Migrating them to Integration Suite is not just about tool-based conversion but about adopting patterns that keep the setup clean and maintainable in the long run. With the right approach in place, the transition becomes less of a migration task and more of a steady move toward a simplified, future-ready integration landscape.

entry.title: 2H 2025 Release Highlights: New innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
With the 2H 2025 release, we have delivered new capabilities within SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to improve how organizations attract and hire the best talent.  

Through customer influence on the Customer Community and innovative product enhancements, we are bringing your ideas to life and driving improvements across the recruiting experience.

To learn more watch the on-demand Q&A webinars: 2H 2025 Product Release Webinars and Recruiting & Onboarding 2H 2025 Customer Release Q&A. To hear more about the roadmap and broader view of our strategy, watch the VIP Virtual Program for Strategic Roadmap Updates.    

All of the 2H 2025 release items can be found on the What‚Äôs New Viewer. These new features will be live in Production on November 16th, 2025.

This release brings enhanced AI-driven capabilities to the SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding solution, enabling hiring teams to streamline key onboarding activities, improve offboarding, and accelerate hiring.

Auto-completion of new hire activities

With auto-completion of new hire activities, administrators can now automate routine onboarding tasks, administrators can now automate routine onboarding tasks, like preparing for day one and writing welcome messages. This saves time in high-volume and bulk hiring scenarios, ensures consistency, and lets hiring managers and new hires focus on a successful start.

AI-assisted document processing

AI-assisted document processing further enhances onboarding by automatically extracting information from IDs and passports to support employee verification, ensuring compliance while reducing manual input.

Redesigned offboarding dashboard

The redesigned offboarding dashboard provides a clear, unified view for HR and hiring manager to track progress, minimize delays, and deliver a smooth transition from employee to alumni.

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for Onboarding

A new embedded extensibility wizard feature from SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is now available within Onboarding. This powerful tool guides users through creating custom application extensions, such as adding unique data fields or tailoring business processes. By simplifying customization, the extensibility wizard helps customers quickly add the fields and workflows they need to reduce time spent on manual updates and make it easier to complete tasks accurately.

Continuously Delivering Enhancements     

With every release, we are excited to deliver these new innovations and continue our journey of providing even greater value to our customers. For full details, please check out the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Resources: 

  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Brochure
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Video 
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights News Article  
  • Product Release & Road Map Information

Learn more about SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding.

entry.title: Emission Factors on SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Which emission factors are all provided by SAP? Is it possible to share a list of all the emission factors Excel file or is there a way to download it from somewhere? 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Emission Factors on SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
SAP provides default emission factor data that includes the following data packages from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA):

  • EPA-2023
  • EPA-2023-Spend
  • EPA-2024

These packages contain emission factors for Scope 1 ‚Äì Stationary combustion, Scope 2 ‚Äì Purchased electricity, steam, and heat, and Scope 3 - Waste Generated in Operations and End-of-Life Treatment of Sold Products. Users can access this information in the Manage Emission Factors app itself and export the data packages via Excel file or refer to the Using Data Published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency guide for more details.

For additional government-provided emission factor data, please consult the Using Default Emission Factor Data guide.

entry.title: Availability check in sales order not available after delivery is created
entry.content:
Hello Community, 

I have the following situation:

MaterialStock
A0
B5
C10
D0

 

We create a sales order with material A requesting 30 units but material A doesn't have stock. As it has material B and C as substitutes, sales order gets created like this: 

ItemMaterialOrder QuantityConfirmed Qty
10A3015
11B55
12C1010
13A150

 

Then customer is creating the delivery with lines 11 and 12 as they have confirmed quantities. Units of line 13 goes to backorder. Then customer received some stock for material D, they want to execute availability check so that sales order gets updated with a new line with the available material and quantities for backorder are reduced. 

However, once we create the delivery we are not able to execute item availability again. Line with the original requested material has schedule line category CN and the substitutes have schedule line category CP.

Could someone help us mentioning why availability check is not working after we create the delivery if the sales order allows partial deliveries and how can we make it work?

 

Thanks a lot.

entry.title: Bring your own Hugging Face Transformers in SAP AI Foundation
entry.content:
üåüIntroduction

At SAP TechEd 2025, I demonstrated how to operationalize Hugging Face Transformer models in SAP AI Foundation using the Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) approach.

The goal was to show how I can move beyond consuming pre-hosted APIs and instead own the full model lifecycle ‚Äì from training to serving inside SAP BTP.

My showcase focused on blocked invoice classification in SAP S/4HANA, a common process bottleneck.

Using BYOM, I trained and deployed a custom NLP model that predicts why an invoice was blocked, helping finance teams accelerate processing and reduce manual work.

üîçWhy BYOM Matters

BYOM enables organizations and developers to:

  • Train, deploy, and govern their own models rather than relying on third-party APIs.
  • Maintain full control of data, model weights, and compliance.
  • Reuse open-source innovation (such as Hugging Face Transformers) within the secure boundaries of SAP BTP.
  • Adapt models continuously to evolving business data without vendor lock-in.

This approach contrasts with SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub, where models are pre-hosted by SAP or partners and accessed via API only.

With BYOM, I define the model architecture, container image, and YAML-based orchestration.

SAP AI Core executes these workflows securely, while AI Launchpad provides lifecycle management, logging, and governance.

üß† Use Case: Blocked Invoice Classification

Invoices in SAP S/4HANA can be blocked for reasons such as mismatched quantities, missing purchase orders, or pricing errors.

To automate this review, I fine-tuned a DeBERTa-v3-base model from Hugging Face on labeled invoice text.

Label map:

Label Category

0Price Variance
1Quantity Mismatch
2Missing PO Reference
3Three-Way Match Failure
4Supplier Issues

‚öôÔ∏èBYOM Architecture in SAP AI Foundation

The BYOM setup in SAP AI Core uses modular components that I can fully customize and version-control.

 

This architecture allows me to deploy, retrain, and scale models independently while maintaining full ownership of data and artifacts.

üß© End-to-End BYOM Flow

Below is a visual representation of the Bring Your Own Model workflow that connects all components:

This diagram illustrates how:

  • The GitHub repository stores YAML templates (training-template.yaml, serving-template.yaml) and runtime configurations that sync with AI Core.
  • AI Core executes deployments using Docker images stored in the Docker Registry.
  • The KServe InferenceService (FastAPI) runs inside AI Core and is consumed by CAP or Fiori applications.
  • SAP AI Launchpad provides a single interface for monitoring, versioning, and managing deployments.

üß≠ Preparing SAP AI Core for BYOM

Before deploying the model, I performed several key setup steps to prepare SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for BYOM:

  1. Create AI Core and AI Launchpad Instances ‚Äì provisioned both services on SAP BTP for orchestration and lifecycle management.
  2. Create a Resource Group ‚Äì isolated compute and storage resources for this project.
  3. Set Up Docker Registry Connection ‚Äì linked my private registry and created a secret (docker-registry-secret).
  4. Onboard the GitHub Repository ‚Äì connected the repo to AI Core so YAML templates stay in sync with AI Launchpad.
  5. Register Datasets and Model Artifacts ‚Äì uploaded CSVs and defined output artifact paths.
  6. Create API Client ‚Äì generated credentials for pipeline execution.
  7. Validate Configuration ‚Äì ran a quick smoke test to confirm all mounts, secrets, and permissions were functional.

 

 

This one-time configuration ensures a seamless transition between local development and enterprise-grade orchestration in AI Core.

üß© Training Pipeline (Bring Your Own Training Logic)

I created a training template (training-template.yaml) that runs my PyTorch script inside AI Core:

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: WorkflowTemplate
metadata:
  name: invoice-classifier-training
spec:
  arguments:
    parameters:
      - name: trainImage
        value: "docker.io/itsmarlo/invoice-train:latest"
      - name: baseModel
        value: "microsoft/deberta-v3-base"
      - name: numLabels
        value: "5"

The workflow fine-tunes the model, evaluates it, and stores the trained weights as an artifact.

All training logic, hyperparameters, and dependencies are defined by me, illustrating the ‚Äúbring your own‚Äù principle in action.

Training dependencies (requirements-train.txt)

torch==2.3.1
transformers>=4.42.0
datasets>=2.20.0
scikit-learn>=1.4.2
pandas>=2.2.2

üß† Serving Pipeline (Bring Your Own Inference Service)

The serving template (serving-template.yaml) deploys the model as a REST API using a lightweight FastAPI application:

apiVersion: ai.sap.com/v1alpha1
kind: ServingTemplate
metadata:
  name: invoice-classifier-serving
spec:
  parameters:
    - name: image
      default: "docker.io/itsmarlo/invoice-serve:latest"
    - name: port
      default: 8080

Serving stack (requirements-serve.txt)

fastapi>=0.111.0
uvicorn[standard]>=0.30.0
torch==2.3.1
transformers>=4.42.0
pydantic>=2.7.0

AI Core hosts this container as a KServe inference service that scales automatically and can be consumed securely by any SAP application.

üßæ Testing the BYOM Deployment

I validated the deployed endpoint directly from AI Launchpad and Postman:

curl -X POST "https://<aicore-endpoint>/v1/invocations" \\
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \\
  -d '{"text":"Invoice blocked due to mismatch between PO and invoice quantity"}'

Response:

{
 "predicted_label": "Quantity Mismatch",
 "confidence": 0.94
}

üß© Integration into SAP Applications

I integrated the inference endpoint with:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) for data exchange
  • SAP CAP services calling the AI Core endpoint
  • Fiori Elements UI showing predictions in blocked-invoice apps

This completes the BYOM loop ‚Äì training in AI Core, serving through KServe, and consuming predictions in SAP S/4HANA.

üí°Key Insights from Building a BYOM Scenario

  • Validate locally first: Most deployment issues come from path or dependency errors.
  • Keep Docker architecture consistent: Always build for linux/amd64.
  • Version everything: YAMLs, images, and datasets must align.
  • Secure storage early: Validate S3 credentials and IAM roles.
  • Test endpoints before integration: Simple Postman tests save time.

Each step underlines the strength of BYOM: complete visibility and control of the AI lifecycle.

üìàResults

Metric Value

Base modelDeBERTa-v3-base
Training time‚âà 10 min (3 epochs, batch 16)
Model size‚âà 250 MB
Validation accuracy‚âà 90 %
Inference latency< 200 ms (CPU)

üî≠Next Steps

I plan to enhance the BYOM pipeline by:

  • Adding a metrics logging stage to AI Launchpad
  • Automating retraining with updated datasets
  • Integrating model explainability (SHAP, LIME)
  • Monitoring inference performance in real time

üß™ Try It Yourself

You can explore the full setup, including all YAML templates, Dockerfiles, and sample datasets, in my public GitHub repository:

üëâGitHub ‚Äì teched25-BYOM-classifier

Clone the repo, adjust the dataset paths, and deploy your own BYOM workflow on SAP AI Core.

The repository includes:

  • Training and serving templates for AI Core
  • Dockerfiles for both training and serving containers
  • Python scripts for model fine-tuning and inference
  • Example datasets and label maps

This example is a starting point for deploying your own Hugging Face models in SAP AI Foundation with full lifecycle control.

‚ö†Ô∏èChallenges and How I Overcame Them

Challenge Resolution

Image pull failures due to architecture mismatch (ARM vs. x86)Rebuilt Docker images specifically for linux/amd64, ensuring compatibility with AI Core runtimes.
Path mismatches and missing dependenciesValidated Docker builds locally before pushing to Docker Hub; used absolute paths for mounted datasets in YAML templates.
Dataset access issues (S3 permissions)Adjusted IAM policy and verified bucket configuration early in the setup.
Versioning conflicts between Docker images and YAML definitionsImplemented strict version tagging across all artifacts to maintain reproducibility.
Debugging failed executionsUsed AI Launchpad logs extensively and added print statements in Python scripts to trace errors.

Each challenge reinforced the value of BYOM‚Äîhaving full transparency and ownership made it easier to troubleshoot, iterate, and optimize the overall AI lifecycle.

üôåConclusion

This project demonstrates how Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) empowers developers to run open-source models like Hugging Face Transformers within SAP AI Foundation under full enterprise governance.

By defining my own Docker images, YAML pipelines, and inference logic, I combined open innovation with SAP‚Äôs orchestration and compliance framework.

The result is an end-to-end, production-ready AI service for SAP S/4HANA that remains explainable, auditable, and reusable across use cases.

Follow me on SAP Community for more insights on BYOM, Hugging Face integration, and AI Core automation.ü§ó

entry.title: ASUG Tech Connect 2025 summary: vibe coding, UX innovation, and AI everywhere
entry.content:
ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville, Kentucky, delivered big on both technology and connection. From the opening keynote to the final session, there were many examples of how AI improves both developer and business user productivity. While all the generative AI technologies are revolutionary and potentially very disruptive to organizations that ignore their impact, it was great to see AI applied in a variety of ways from creating ABAP code to moving Z-transactions in a clean core methodology. In this post, I‚Äôll highlight a few important themes, along with several moments at ASUG Tech Connect that made an impact on me. In each section, I‚Äôll provide some questions for you to discuss with your team.

ABAP is still going strong

The session ‚ÄúExtensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP‚Äù says it all. Jens and Raghavendra  showed that ABAP has new generative AI tools that you can use to extend standard SAP Fiori apps and build new custom apps. With so many customers still contemplating their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the ability to use familiar skills makes it easier to transition.

AI-powered features make SAP Cloud ERP even easier to use

In ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Next: AI-First Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite‚Äù, Ullas and I showed several new embedded features to boost business users‚Äô productivity, most of which were powered by AI. Demos included a mix of released functionality, features in beta, and even a sneak preview of something from our lab. We received lots of great feedback on how people plan to use smart helpers if we bring this to market.

My Home for SAP S/4HANA

SAP Fiori elements apps

  • AI-assisted enterprise search
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
  • AI-assisted smart solutions for situations in My Home
  • Recap
  • Joule
  • AI-assisted easy filter
  • AI-assisted smart summarization
  • AI-assisted easy fill
  • AI-assisted error explanation
  • Smart Helpers (working name ‚Äì sneak preview)

Ask yourself:

  • Do your business users still spend too much time on manual navigation?
  • Could a smart home screen or conversational interface drastically reduce that?
  • What is holding you back from adopting AI in your organization?

No-code, low-code, and pro-code are converging with vibe coding

In ‚ÄúUsing Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development‚Äù Ullas demonstrated how code-generation, conversational interfaces, and tooling changes are altering how we build apps. Using VS Code and Cline, connected to an SAP back end, he created a fully functional app, including CAP service and sample data, using only text prompts ‚Äì no coding at all. He started the app creation process by loading an image of what he wanted, then added functionality by asking Cline to build it. When error messages came up, he pasted screen shots back into the tool and asked it to fix the error. This can reduce the time to create a first prototype from weeks to hours. Skilled developers are required for making sure the app is production worthy, testing, and putting into production. We had some customers share their experience using coding agents and appreciation for how SAP packaged this to simplify the process. Some plan to expand their efforts on this journey and potentially share their stories in next year‚Äôs ASUG Tech Connect or SAP TechEd.

Ask yourself:

  • How much more AI can you use to accelerate development?
  • What would you need to see to gain confidence that you can use it for building apps?
  • Can you rebuild some of your old customizations in a clean core way to make your IT environment more agile?

SAP Fiori is essential to capture the full value of your SAP Cloud ERP implementation

My session on ‚ÄúCreating better user experiences with AI-powered SAP Fiori apps‚Äù discussed how SAP Fiori is a critical part of generating value from using SAP S/4HANA. Most of the audience had some Fiori experience and most were using AI in some way in their organization in some way.

 

The session started with the origins of Fiori and highlighted the huge leap in usability from the old SAP GUI screens to the intuitive, agile, and intelligent UX that My Home and SAP Fiori apps provide. It included a demo of many of the UX innovations in SAP Cloud ERP today, and discussion of how to get started with Fiori in your organization.

View slides from ‚ÄúCreating better user experiences with AI-powered SAP Fiori apps‚Äù session.

The main message was to get started now on your UX transformation now to provide your employees with a better user experience and access to AI-assisted capabilities that are built int SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Ask yourself:

  • What is holding us back from using more Fiori in the organization? Is it resistance from the users themselves, IT, or the business owners?
  • How do we quantify the business value of SAP Fiori in terms of higher user productivity, better data quality, lower training costs, and reduced cost of making changes to screens?

Clean core is necessary for digital transformation

The topic of clean core, meaning minimizing customizations to the SAP S/4HANA environment, was reinforced everywhere. The hand-on sessions ‚ÄúBuild On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP‚Äù and ‚ÄúModernize Classic Extensions for Clean Core‚Äù emphasized how you can use clean core principles and still build customizations to fit your business‚Äôs unique needs. Andre, Nora, and Ullas explained how to do this and guided people through practical exercises.

Ask yourself:

  • How much customization do you need to run your business? (Less is more!)
  • Can you use standard apps for more processes than you are doing today?
  • What is the cost of maintaining your custom code and how much is custom code preventing you from adopting the latest SAP ERP versions?

You don‚Äôt have to move to SAP Cloud ERP on your own

With such a broad collection of industries represented at ASUG Tech Connect, it was easy to find someone who had already solved the challenges you are facing. That‚Äôs the whole point of attending a large networking event like this ‚Äì to connect with like-minded individuals who want to move forward and need a little help (or push). I was fortunate to have many interesting breakfast, lunch, and break conversations about where people are struggling with moving their users to SAP Fiori apps.

The colleagues from Naturipe Farms, Brian and Dario, shared some of their experiences in ‚ÄúCustomer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe.‚Äù It was the third year in a row that they are presenting, so it‚Äôs great to follow their progress. Next year they plan to share their progress with a vibe-coding approach.

Ask yourself:

  • What communities can you join to learn from peers? ASUG, SAP Fiori development roundtable?
  • What thought leaders do you follow on LinkedIn that you can learn from?

There is no technology change without people change

It‚Äôs always the ‚Äúsoft skills‚Äù sessions that surprise me at SAP events with the lasting impact they make. Perhaps this is because the fundamental principles don‚Äôt change from year to year with new technology innovations, so they generally have more staying power. The panel on ‚ÄúLeading change in the age of AI: driving digital transformation through emotionally intelligent communication‚Äù had many great insights for business and technology leaders who are steering their organizations through the massive changes that an SAP S/4HANA upgrade, SAP Fiori implementation, or AI adoption brings. Some key takeaways included: focusing on business outcomes and ensuring that people can grow from the changes.

Ask yourself:

  • How can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issues.
  • What happens to my organization if we do nothing?

Get comfortable being uncomfortable

This is a time of rapid change for enterprise software and business in general. The AI tools have frequent updates in which their capabilities improve in some areas and don‚Äôt in others. It‚Äôs hard to keep up with all this, but critical. Nvidia CEO, Jensen Huang says ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to lose your job to AI. You‚Äôre going to lose your job to someone who uses AI.‚Äù Change is a part of progress; get used to it.

Ask yourself:

  • What new AI-related skills have you learned in the next month?
  • Where can you try some AI in your business that will allow you to learn with low risk?

Next steps:

  • Review the slides, which are available to attendees on the ASUG Tech Connect website.
  • Start exploring AI tools for development now. Even if you are not ready to incorporate them into your core business processes, you need to gain experience using them if you want to stay relevant in the industry.
  • Identify two use cases where AI can make a measurable business impact. Build a proof of concept in your test environment or sandbox system to measure the return on investment.
  • Follow the speakers of sessions that you liked on LinkedIn. You will gain insights into what they are working on and likely see innovations as soon as they become available.
  • Subscribe to our SAP Fiori development newsletter, where will share new innovations for application development as soon as they are available.

entry.title: How to use reserved words as property names in your OData service?
entry.content:
Introduction

Sometimes

there is the requirement to use field names that are reserved words such as Number, Begin or other reserved words as a propery property name of your OData service, e.g. to fill the value of a dynamic tile.

Implementation

When trying to set this name as an alias in your CDS view this fails with the error message: 

NUMBER is a reserved word (choose another field name) .

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Products'

define view entity ZI_VH_PRODUCT
  as select from zproducts
{
  key product       as Product,
      producttext   as Producttext,
      productgroup  as ProductGroup,
      price         as Price,
      currency      as Currency,
      baseunit      as BaseUnit,
      numberinstock as Number
}

Solution

Using the annotation @odata.property.name this can be achieved for RAP based OData services.

In the CDS view that is used by your OData service it is possible to add the following annotation

@odata.property.name: 'Number'

to the source code of the CDS view.   

This way the name of the CDS view property can be such that it does comply to the validations of the CDS editor, but at the same time the name of this field in the OData Service would be set to Number.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Test'
@ObjectModel.query.implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_VH_PRODUCTS'

define view entity ZI_VH_PRODUCT
  as select from zproducts
{
  key product       as Product,
      producttext   as Producttext,
      productgroup  as ProductGroup,
      price         as Price,
      currency      as Currency,
      baseunit      as BaseUnit,
      @odata.property.name: 'Number'
      numberinstock as NumberInStock
}

As a result you will get the following result in the $metadata call.

<EntityType Name="Product2Type">
<Key>
<PropertyRef Name="Product"/>
</Key>
<Property Name="Product" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="Producttext" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="ProductGroup" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="Price" Type="Edm.Decimal" Nullable="false" Precision="15" Scale="variable"/>
<Property Name="Currency" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="5"/>
<Property Name="BaseUnit" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="3"/>
<Property Name="Number" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="3"/>
</EntityType>

Also the Fiori Elements Preview shows the wished result:

entry.title: Cross delivery handling unit in Advanced shipping and receiving (ASR) in SAP S/4HANA 2025 release
entry.content:
Cross delivery handling unit means a packing box (like carton) containing products from multiple deliveries as shown in below image. Carton P contains product A and B from two deliveries X and Y respectively. Cross delivery handling unit is very effective for small parts, optimization of packing etc. 

Cross delivery handling unit is supported in SAP Extended warehouse management (EWM). Capability for cross handling unit for Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) with Transportation unit (TU) is supported from SAP S/4HANA 2021 release . Refer my blog https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/cross-delivery-handling-unit-in-tm-ewm-integration-in-s-4hana-2021-release/ba-p/13514920.

Advanced shipping & receiving (ASR) is a new solution for integration between Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) in SAP S/4HANA. ASR eliminates the requirement of Transportation unit (TU) in EWM and LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) or web service communication between TM & EWM. This new ASR solution was introduced in FPS1 of SAP S/4HANA 2020 release and is evolving with S/4HANA releases. Refer my  blog https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mrinalkroy_ewm-tm-s4hana-activity-6996835047068610560-e3V7?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAACqeFcBFLp4MZaIFhaLzuKFWx73dXzaU2U for more details on ASR.

Cross delivery handling unit is now supported in ASR too from S/4HANA 2025 release. My present blog is to describe the functionality of cross delivery handling unit in ASR .

Two outbound deliveries (80004555 and 80004556) relevant for ASR have been depicted in below image.

These deliveries are blocked for warehouse execution as in below image as they are transportation driven (i.e will be blocked till the relevant freight order is set for ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô.  

Freight order 6600000909 is now created with freight units created from those deliveries and then set of ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô . Subsequently EWM outbound deliveries also got released for warehouse execution as depicted in below image.

A handling unit 812345678000001816               is created packing both the items (products) from those deliveries as displayed in below image .

This handling unit then gets displayed as ‚ÄòCross -D HU‚Äô as highlighted in below image for both deliveries.

Both of the EWM outbound deliveries then need to be ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô. 

As these deliveries have a single handling unit , both of the deliveries need to be selected for ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô . otherwise error as in below image appears if a single delivery is chosen.

Handling unit then appears in freight order as in below image.

Handling unit is subsequently loaded to the truck and ‚ÄòPost‚Äô or Goods issue is executed.

One of the pre-requisites for cross handling unit is that the consolidation group needs to be same , otherwise below error appears.

This blog is based on my personal tests , observations , insights in S/4HANA 2025 release. Will appreciate your feedback / comments.

entry.title: Re: Test data refresh SAP service prior to go live
entry.content:
Good day @phaneste02 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Test Data Refresh, Migration Cockpit, Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit, Recommendations to Integrate 3-System Landscape, System Landscapes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

https://help.sap.com/doc/854aff5e1cb34ae3b7244eae04f719d6/SHIP/en-US/5169e9a506e94db99bf41eb8470a62d0.pdf

Based on your description, it seems you are in the Explore phase of your public cloud 3SL and want to prepare a data migration mock-up by cleaning out poor quality sprint data in the Test system before UAT.

To summarise, in public cloud 3SL, the Test Data Refresh Service can only be used after your project‚Äôs go-live, when you have a production system. This service copies master and transactional data from production to Test but cannot be executed before the P system is provisioned.

In your current phase, SAP does not support copying or refreshing data between tenants. You can however, achieve your goal of a clean, migration-ready Test tenant through one of the following supported options:

It is most recommended to request for Tenant Reinitialization by opening an incident with SAP. Make sure you ask for all transactional configuration data to be deleted. Inform them it is required for data migration mock-up and clean UAT baseline.

Second is to use migration cockpit for data cleanup.

Open Migrate Your Data- Migration Cockpit.

 Third is to use migration templates to overwrite or delete incorrect master and transactional data. Thereafter, reload your complete mock-up migration dataset for testing.

If you still have access to the Starter tenant, load and validate your migration templates there. Once you have finalized that, re-use those same templates in the Test tenant for your UAT baseline.

After go-live, when you Production system is available, you can request the Test Data Refresh Service through SAP Cloud Operations to copy for future regression or post-go-live testing cycles.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Field Selection for RFQ Document (Ext. Sourcing Req.)...
entry.content:
Hello @sans16 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

App Extensibility: Manage RFQs, Service Procurement, Field Selection, Processing of Field Selection String & Integration with SAP Ariba

Based on your description, it seems your client‚Äôs requirement is to adjust mandatory and optional fields on the RFQ creation screen in public cloud. Specifically, to make some standard fields optional and others mandatory on sourcing responsibility between s4H and Ariba.

To summarise, in public cloud, the field control for purchasing documents such as RFQ, Purchase Order etc, is pre-delivered by SAP and you cannot change them through direct customizing which you can in private cloud and on-premise. The configuration node Field Selection is not exposed as an SSCUI in public cloud. However, there are some limited clean-core alternatives you can consider:

  1. First is to use Adapt UI to hide fields that your S4H users don‚Äôt need to maintain manually. While you cannot change the mandatory logic, you can surely hide unnecessary fields for internal users. You can achieve this by:

Opening your Manage RFQ app --> User Actions --> Adapt UI. Select a field --> Choose Hide Field --> Save as New Variant.

  1. Second option is to use BadIs for field validation by using Custom Logic app for limited field validation. Implement MM_PUR_RFQ_CHECK. You can create custom validation logic to enforce mandatory entry or allow optional entry based on your conditions. An example would be if external sourcing=true, then skip validation.
  2. Third option is for the Field relevance to follow the Ariba sourcing templates instead of S4H field setting if your business process is managed by Ariba external sourcing. Alos in the case mandatory fields are controlled in Ariba configuration.
  3. Final option is for you to raise a Feature Request if needed with SAP

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to connect SAP PO running over netweaver 7.50 with OpenText XML Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's digital landscape, enterprises rely heavily on seamless integration between platforms to maintain agility, optimize operations, and enhance digital transformation initiatives. SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) is a comprehensive integration software that enables the synchronization of processes and data across numerous SAP and non-SAP applications. One such integration possibility involves connecting SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API to facilitate efficient document management capabilities.

OpenText is a leading enterprise information management company known for its robust solutions, including its SOAP API which provides functionalities for document management. Integrating SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API allows organizations to achieve a streamlined connection between their business processes and their document management systems, thereby enhancing access to vital information and documents.

Before embarking on this integration journey, several key considerations must be addressed, including authentication mechanisms, message format mapping, and error handling. Given that SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) relies on XML-based messaging protocols, mastering these elements is critical for a successful and secure integration. This article will guide you through the essential steps for establish a secure connection to OpenText's SOAP API and offer insights into how to authenticate users and manage documents effectively.

Goal

The goal of this article is to guide enterprises on connecting a legacy system to OpenText using SAP PO, and to generate a single endpoint that encapsulates multiple requests to different services exposed by OpenText. By achieving this, organizations can streamline their document management processes, reduce complexity, and enhance the efficiency of their operations.

 

The first step in order to achieve the integration of both systems will be to Establishing a secure and reliable connection between SAP PO and OpenText's SOAP API requires robust authentication mechanisms.

In this case we will delve into the basic authentication. Understanding this methodology is crucial for safeguarding your data and ensuring authorized access only.

Once authenticated, the core of the integration lies in the consumption of document management features offered by the OpenText SOAP API. This section offers a step-by-step guide on how to configure SAP PO to interact with OpenText's document management functionalities.

To simplify, the basic architecture will be structured this way.

A single interface is presented to the legacy system, which is then divided within SAP PI to engage multiple interfaces based on a custom tag referred to as method.

Step 1.

Generate a single data type with a common structure for the services that will be consolidated on one.

The following Data Type will be used as the request

And this Data Type will be used for the response

Transformation process involve several use of graphical mapping and XSLT transformations in order to achieve the goal to get a single entry point for all the exposed services, with the graphical mappings allowing to include transformations and validations in order to detect the data type received 

Step 2 

Define the graphical message mappings for request and response, one for each inbound service interface defined.

Step 3

At the response graphical mapping, add custom java functions in order to identify and set the data type of the values that are returning, the custom functions must to be embedded inside the mapping and be called as custom functions.

This custom function receive 5 entry parameters that are returned by the opentext get node method, evaluate the data type of the value and return a single text with the description of the type, the goal of this is reduce the complexity of the logic at the legacy system.

Here is the Java code of the custom function

 

at also another custom function was developed to validate the data type of any value returned at the Values tag

Step 4

Build the XSLT transformations in order to adapt the structure to the opentext services, this will add the corresponding namespaces, eliminate non necessary tags and generate the parents when will be need it.

Step 5.

Build the operation mapping that will be in charge of call sequentially the graphical message mapping and the XSLT transformations, this operation mapping will have one step for request and another for response considering the process defined as Synchronous.

Request side will at first call the graphical mapping and at second will use the XSLT transformation

The response side will call the XSLT transformation that will adapt the structure, then add the namespace and at last use the graphical mapping where the custom java functions are located

Once all the steps are done and the iFlow is created and deployed the service could be tested using SOAP UI.

 

Conclusion

This approach allow to generate a single endpoint to consume some specific methods of the Opentext implementation, allowing to get an homogeneous structure at response, but will require some work if new methods will be implemented, at also the architecture could be considered slightly coupled since maintenance could be required as well but not frequently.

The current architecture could face several challenges to be migrated to SAP Integration Suite running over BTP

entry.title: Complete Guide: Setting Up CAP Plugin for Advanced Event Mesh with OAuth Authentication
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the result of the steps taken to successfully use the official CAP plugin for Advanced Event Mesh. It took some time to set it up through a series of trial-and-error approaches. I knew I couldn't keep everything in mind, so initially this content was intended to be the README.md file of the resulting repository.

There is plenty of material in the Community that speaks about the setup steps of the prerequisites, including a dedicated chapter in the official SAP Help:

  • Securing SAP Advanced Event Mesh: OAuth Configuration and SEMP API Integration by Carlos Roggan
  • Securing Advanced Event Mesh: Comprehensive Guide to OAuth Configuration in Broker Manager by Carlos Roggan
  • SAP Cloud Integration: Advanced Event Mesh Adapter series, also by Carlos Roggan
  • Setup CAP Plugin from the official documentation

This blog ties all these pieces together into a single end-to-end guide.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  • An active subscription of Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), or a subaccount in which you have AEM entitlement
  • Administrative access to Identity Authentication Services (IAS)
  • Cloud Foundry CLI installed and configured
  • A REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL)
  • CAP development environment set up

Scope of This Guide

Important: This guide covers Authentication only, not Authorization, and specifically for the CAP Plugin. All other use cases are already covered in the referenced blogs by Carlos Roggan.

Values Reference Guide

Throughout this guide, we'll collect several values that will be reused multiple times. Values highlighted in green are critical configuration values you'll need to reference later. Keep them in a secure note-taking application as you progress through the steps.

 

SAP Identity Authentication Services

The CAP plugin requires OAuth-based access to work. We need an Identity Provider capable of generating JWT tokens for connecting to the AEM Service. For this, we'll use Identity Authentication Services (IAS).

Create an OIDC Application

Navigate to the IAS Administration console, then select the Application & Resources menu entry:

  • Select Create from the header of the left-side navigation list
  • Fill in the following attributes:
    • Application Name: Choose a descriptive name
    • Type: Set to SAP BTP Solution
    • Protocol Type: Set to OpenID Connect
  • Select Create

The Application Details page opens. Complete these two configuration steps:

Configure OpenID Connect

  • Select the OpenID Connect Configuration list entry
    • Enter a configuration name (can be any descriptive name), then select Save
    • Scroll down to the Grant Types section
    • Ensure that Client Credentials, JWT Bearer, and Refresh Token are toggled On
    • You may enable other options, but they are not required for this guide

Create Client Credentials

  • Scroll down to Client Authentication and select this list entry
  • Navigate to the Secrets section and select Add
  • This creates a dedicated Client ID and corresponding Client Secret for JWT token generation:
    • Enter a meaningful name for the secret
    • Select the OIDC Scopes: at minimum, choose OpenID
    • Select Save

‚ö†Ô∏èCRITICAL: Copy the Client ID and Client Secret from the pop-up immediately. The secret cannot be retrieved later‚Äîif lost, you'll need to generate a new one.

Collect IAS Configuration Values

Before proceeding to AEM configuration, collect these values. Fields in green are required for creating the OAuth Profile in the Broker Manager:

  • Client ID (from the previous step)
  • Client Secret (from the previous step)
  • OIDC Issuer Information:
    • Navigate to Application & Resources ‚Üí Tenant Settings ‚Üí Single Sign-On ‚Üí OpenID Connect Configuration
    • Copy the URL value from the Issuer section: this is your Issuer Identifier
    • Select the Show Discovery Endpoint button
    • Copy the URL from the browser window that opens: this is your Discovery Endpoint

Test Token Generation

Let's verify that the client credentials can successfully generate JWT tokens.

Using your preferred REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL), execute the following request:

curl -X POST "https://youriastenant/oauth2/token" \
-H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" \
-d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
-d "client_id=" \
-d "client_secret=" \
-d "token_format=jwt"

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with a response similar to:

{
  "access_token": "eyJqa3UiOiJodHRwczovL2FtY21nYmpwZS5hY2NvdW50cy5jbG91ZC5zYXAvb2F1dGgyL2NlcnRzIiwia2lkIjoiTjdvNU1aSW5jR1ltelIzcmtNaVlTYkZWcW1zIiwiYWxnIjoiUlMyNTYifQ..NvjwTzyfua785jqLWGWkDP7quLhFMzVhundvMjitkOWVr3snb7pL0Z3nHNvHy0qYo6DadIpSHUVA3pchAR0xvhlXKgIRhX4hMRp2T1JzNTm9sVV7Mv92Bxt3Q990-vQh3DhHZj_pkqvDMflo8hpcobgXwQyy0sXGPI7GM_BChQ74BoqiR9m28jvVKxwtJh18d_Gc4d1J3hJzUxs2m4Gec-Lose7B63WkfwXeeprMW_RLdOCKvOGfuWbMQBPJWjJnfr4ayE3Uq2wEtFZEylFvQjMDsd1otO-_ZRmZwbs76DHf5TD2CBH0Up9LwKH8Ww87gcn9T8ULSbiV4ijQenaa2g",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600
}

Verify Token Contents

Copy the value of the access_token property and navigate to jwt.io. Paste the token value in the left-hand textarea (Encoded section), replacing the default values. You should see the decoded token on the right:

{
  "sub": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "aud": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "azp": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "iss": "https://amcmgbjpe.accounts.cloud.sap",
  "azpacr": "1",
  "exp": 1762800894,
  "iat": 1762797294,
  "jti": "5bfccdab-9902-483b-83e6-50ddd820353f"
}

Note that the sub value matches your Client ID and the iss value is your Identity Authentication tenant (the token issuer).

With IAS successfully configured to generate JWT tokens, we're ready to configure AEM to accept these tokens for authentication.

 

SAP Advanced Event Mesh

(Optional) Create a Service Broker

Skip this step if you already have a Service Broker you'd like to use.

Open the AEM Cluster Manager and select the Create Service button on the Services page. You'll be prompted to provide the following details:

  • Service Name: Choose a descriptive name
  • Cloud Provider: Select your preferred provider (e.g., AWS)
  • Region: Choose the region nearest to you (e.g., eu-south-1)
  • Version: Keep the default or specify a version
  • Service Type: For this tutorial, Developer (Broker-100) is sufficient
  • Advanced Connection Options:
    • Expand this section and review the Message VPN Name
    • It's auto-generated from your Service Name, but you can customize it
    • Choose something memorable‚Äîyou'll need this value frequently

Select Create Service at the bottom right to continue.

Service Broker Details

Create the OAuth Profile for the Broker Manager

Navigate to the Cluster Manager and open your Service Broker.

In the top navigation menu, select Manage, then select the Access Control link in the left-hand navigation menu under Broker Manager Quick Links.

Service Management

The Access Control page opens to the Client Authentication ‚Üí Settings sub-section.

Select OAuth Profile (located after the Settings sub-section). Here we'll create a new OAuth Profile and set it as the default.

OAuth Profile

Select "+ OAuth Profile" in the top-right corner and provide a profile name (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS).

Configure OAuth Profile Attributes

In the configuration screen, fill in the following attributes using the green-highlighted values we collected from IAS:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the profile
OAuth Client IDClient IDFrom IAS Application
OAuth Client Secret
(click Change OAuth Client Secret)		Client SecretFrom IAS Application
OAuth RoleResource ServerAEM acts as resource server
Disconnect on Token ExpirationtrueRecommended for security
Issuer IdentifierIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Discovery EndpointDiscovery EndpointFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Parse Access TokentrueRequired for validation
Validate Access Token AudiencetrueValidates token audience
Required AudienceClient IDFrom IAS Application
Validate Access Token IssuertrueValidates token issuer
Required IssuerIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Validate Access Token ScopefalseNot required for this setup
Validate Access Token TypefalseNot required for this setup

Save the profile.

Create a Client Username

This step is essential for AEM to recognize your Client ID as a valid username. It's simple but easy to forget.

Navigate back to the Access Control page, then select Client Usernames in the main navigation menu:

Client Usernames

Select "+ Client Username" and in the pop-up that appears, enter your Client ID. In the configuration page that opens, set:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the client
Client ProfiledefaultUse default profile
ACL ProfiledefaultUse default ACL
Guaranteed Endpoint Permission Override(leave default)No override needed
Subscription ManagertrueAllow subscription management

Save the Client Username.

Set the Default OAuth Profile

Navigate to Client Authentication ‚Üí Settings, scroll down to the OAuth Authentication setting, and toggle it On. From the drop-down menu, select the profile we just created (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS) as the Default Profile Name:

OAuth Authentication default profile

We're done with the UI-based configuration in AEM! Next, we'll configure the SEMP API.

Add the OAuth Profile to the SEMP API

The CAP plugin uses the SEMP (Solace Element Management Protocol) API to manage broker elements. It requires an OAuth Configuration on the SEMP side as well.

We can reuse the values configured in the Broker Manager, but we must perform these changes using the Solace SEMP REST API (no UI is available).

The SEMP API endpoints are visible from Cluster Manager ‚Üí Service Details under the Connect section. Scroll down to Connect with Management Tools:

SEMP

To create the OAuth Profile initially, we need:

  • A personal access token for authentication
  • Your Service technical ID
  • The Solace Cloud API endpoint

Create a Personal Access Token

From the Cluster Manager page, select the User icon at the bottom left, then select Token Management.

Select Create Token in the top-right corner. Provide a token name and select the required scopes. For experimentation, you can select all scopes. For more information, see the Solace API documentation.

Select Create Token at the bottom right and copy the generated token immediately‚Äîyou won't be able to view it again.

Get the Service Technical ID

Navigate to Cluster Manager ‚Üí Service Details for your service and scroll down to the Availability and Versioning section. Copy the Service ID.

Call the Solace Cloud API

Using your preferred REST client, execute the following request. Replace the placeholders in the JSON payload:

AttributeValue
clientIdClient ID
clientSecretClient Secret
endpointDiscoveryDiscovery Endpoint
oauthProfileNameChoose a unique profile name (e.g., "clientcredentials_ias")
resourceServerRequiredIssuerIssuer Identifier
resourceServerRequiredAudienceClient ID

Replace <your_service_id> with your Service technical ID and <your_PAT_Token> with your Personal Access Token:

curl --request POST \
--url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token' \
--header 'content-type: application/json' \
--data '{
  "clientId": "Client ID",
  "clientSecret": "Client Secret",
  "defaultGlobalAccessLevel": "read-only",
  "defaultMsgVpnAccessLevel": "read-write",
  "enabled": true,
  "endpointDiscovery": "Discovery Endpoint",
  "issuer": "Issuer",
  "oauthProfileName": "clientcredentials_ias",
  "oauthRole": "resource-server",
  "resourceServerParseAccessTokenEnabled": false,
  "resourceServerValidateIssuerEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredIssuer": "Issuer",
  "resourceServerValidateAudienceEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredAudience": "Client ID",
  "resourceServerValidateTypeEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredType": "JWT",
  "resourceServerValidateScopeEnabled": false,
  "sempEnabled": true
}'

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with the complete OAuth Profile definition.

‚ö†Ô∏èTroubleshooting: If you receive an error like "Your permissions have changed," verify your Personal Access Token is correct.

Modifying the Profile

Inspect the returned JSON and verify all values. If corrections are needed, you must delete and recreate the profile (PUT/PATCH operations are not supported):

curl --request DELETE \
  --url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles/ \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token'

Then execute the POST request again with corrected values. Repeat as needed until the configuration is correct.

Test the SEMP Configuration

Let's verify the new OAuth Configuration in SEMP works correctly.

We'll obtain an access token from IAS and use it to invoke the SEMP API. This time, we'll use your cluster's SEMP API endpoint (not the global Solace Cloud API).

Replace the placeholder values in the commands below:

# Get IAS Token:
curl --request POST \
  --url https://your_ias_tenant/oauth2/token \
  --header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --data grant_type=client_credentials \
  --data client_id=your_client_id\
  --data response_type=token \
  --data client_secret=your_client_secret

# Call the SEMP API with the generated token:
curl --request GET \
  --url https://your_semp_endpoint:943/SEMP/v2/config/msgVpns//queues \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer ias_generated_token'

Regardless of the JSON response content, the last call should return HTTP 200. If you receive a 401 Unauthorized error, review your OAuth Profile creation and try deleting and recreating it.

 

Integrate with CAP

We've reached the final step‚Äîcreating a CAP application that connects to our Broker using OAuth authentication.

Prerequisites

Following the official documentation, we need:

  • An instance of service aem-validation-service with plan aem-validation-service-plan
  • A user-provided service (UPS) instance containing the IAS and Broker endpoint configuration

Create the AEM Validation Service

Create the service instance and service key:

cf create-service aem-validation-service aem-validation-service-plan 
cf create-service-key

Create the User-Provided Service

Important: The service must be named exactly advanced-event-mesh.

cf create-user-provided-service advanced-event-mesh -p '{
  "authentication-service": {
    "clientid": "your_IAS_Client_ID",
    "clientsecret": "your_IAS_Client_Secret",
    "tokenendpoint": "https://your_IAS_Tenant/oauth2/token"
  },
  "endpoints": {
    "advanced-event-mesh": {
      "smf_uri": "wss://yourserviceendpoint:443",
      "uri": "https://yourserviceendpoint:9443"
    }
  },
  "vpn": "your_service_vpn_name"
}'

Replace all placeholder values with your actual configuration.

Find Endpoint Values

To find values for endpoints.advanced-event-mesh:

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager ‚Üí Service Details ‚Üí Connect
  2. Open the Node.js connection section

Node.Js connection params

  • Select web-messaging to get the smf_uri value
  • Select rest to get the uri value

For the vpn value, navigate to Cluster Manager ‚Üí Service Details, locate the DMR Cluster section, and copy the Message VPN property.

Create the CAP Application

Initialize a new CAP application:

cds init my-aem-powered-app
cd my-aem-powered-app
npm add -js/advanced-event-mesh
npm install
cds bind aem-validation-service -2 aem-validation-service:yourkeyname --for hybrid --kind aem-validation-service
cds bind advanced-event-mesh -2 advanced-event-mesh --for hybrid --kind user-provided

Add a Service Definition

Create a service definition of your choice. This example uses a simple purchase order service:

service AdminService {
    entity PurchaseOrderHeaders as projection on db.PurchaseOrderHeader {
        *,
        items: redirected to PurchaseOrderItems,
        supplier: redirected to Suppliers,
    }
    entity PurchaseOrderItems   as projection on db.PurchaseOrderItem {
        *,
        PurchaseOrderHeader: redirected to PurchaseOrderHeaders
    };
    
    entity Suppliers            as projection on db.Supplier;
}

Configure the Advanced Event Mesh Plugin

Update your .cdsrc.json file to configure the messaging plugin:

{
    "requires": {
        "messaging": {
            "kind": "advanced-event-mesh"
        }
    }
}

Add Event Publishing Logic

Implement logic to publish events when entities are created or updated:

import cds from "@sap/cds";
const LOG = cds.log("admin-service");

export default class AdminService extends cds.ApplicationService {
    async init() {
        await super.init();

        const messaging = await cds.connect.to("messaging");
        
        this.after(["CREATE", "UPDATE"], "PurchaseOrderHeaders", async (data, req) => {
            LOG.info(`Purchase Order ${req.event === 'CREATE' ? 'Created' : 'Updated'} with ID: ${data.ID} and Name: ${data.Name}`);
            
            // Emit the event
            try {
                await messaging.emit(
                    req.event === 'CREATE' ? 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created" : 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated",
                    {
                        ID: data.ID,
                        Name: data.Name,
                    },
                    { 
                        headers: { 
                            "X-Correlation-ID": req.headers["x-correlation-id"] 
                        } 
                    }
                );
            } catch (error) {
                LOG.error(`Error emitting event: ${error.message}`);
                return req.reject(500, `Failed to emit event: ${error.message}`);
            }
        });
    }
}

Run the Application

For initial testing, run the application with the messaging debug flag:

DEBUG=messaging cds watch --profile hybrid

Inspect the terminal output. If everything is configured correctly, you'll see connection logs similar to (abbreviated for brevity):

# ... initialization logs ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: [session-fsm=N/A] [WaitingForDNS] Creating transport session wss://yourserviceendpoint:443/
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Connect Transport WS_BINARY
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Establishing WebSocket transport session
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Constructing socket
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: WebSocket is connecting
# ... [abbreviated for brevity] ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Web transport receive transport event: {
  transportEventCode: 'UP_NOTICE (1)',
  infoStr: 'Connected',
  responseCode: 0,
  errorSubcode: '',
  sid: 'N/A'
}
# ... connection established logs ...
[cds] - connect to messaging > advanced-event-mesh {authentication-service: {...}, endpoints: {...}, vpn: 'yourservicename'}
# ... ready to serve requests ...

End-to-End Test

Before testing the complete flow, set up a subscriber in AEM to receive the published messages.

Connect as a Subscriber

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager ‚Üí Service Details ‚Üí Try Me! section
  2. Note the Client Username and Password displayed
  3. Select Open Broker Manager

Try Me! Page

Configure the Subscriber

In the right-hand Subscriber section:

  1. Connect to the Broker (you may need to uncheck the Same as Publisher option)
  2. Once connected, scroll down to the Subscribe section
  3. Enter the topic you're publishing from CAP:
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated
  4. Select Subscribe

Trigger an Event

Return to your CAP application and create or update a Purchase Order entity. In the AEM Try Me! section, you should see your message appear:

Receiving message on topic

 

Troubleshooting Common Issues

401 Unauthorized on SEMP API

Symptom: SEMP API calls return 401 Unauthorized.

Solution: Verify the OAuth Profile configuration in SEMP. Delete and recreate the profile if necessary, ensuring all values match your IAS configuration.

Token Generation Fails

Symptom: Cannot generate JWT tokens from IAS.

Solution: Verify the Client ID and Client Secret are correct. Ensure the Grant Types (Client Credentials, JWT Bearer) are enabled in the OIDC configuration.

CAP Application Cannot Connect

Symptom: CAP application fails to establish WebSocket connection.

Solution: Verify the user-provided service configuration. Ensure the smf_uri and uri endpoints are correct and the VPN name matches your service. Double check if the OAuth Profile is active and set as default in the Broker Manager.

Conclusion

We covered:

  • Configuring IAS as an OAuth provider
  • Setting up OAuth profiles in AEM Broker Manager and SEMP API
  • Creating and testing a CAP application with event publishing
  • Verifying end-to-end message flow

Thank you for following this long article!

The referenced materials provide additional context and details for specific use cases. Kudos go to the respective authors.

For questions or additional support, please refer to the official SAP documentation or reach out via the SAP Community.

All the best,

Roberto.

entry.title: Top 10 takeaways #SAPTeched 2025
entry.content:
1. The "App-Data-AI" Flywheel is the Core Strategy: SAP has unified its entire strategy under a single "App-Data-AI flywheel" concept. This isn't just new marketing; it‚Äôs a fundamental organizing principle.

The idea is that best-in-class applications (like S/4HANA, SuccessFactors) own business critical transactional data that are key to running the day-to-day of a business. For Insights, The data they generate is leveraged via a harmonized, managed, and governed data layer - the SAP Business Data Cloud.  This clean, context-rich data then powers the new world of AI, which in turn makes the applications smarter.

SAP BTP is the engine for this flywheel, acting as the AI native foundation. This model explains why SAP is so focused on things like data connectivity and new models, that are essential for making this flywheel spin with exponential value.

Teched 1_Apps Data AI

 

 

2. SAP‚Äôs Big Bet: RPT-1, a Foundation Model for Structured Data: In what was arguably the biggest technical reveal, SAP announced SAP RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1), it's first foundation model built specifically for structured, tabular business data.

This is a massive deal.

LLMs are great for text based language, but most business data lives in tables. Until now, solving predictive tasks (like "will this customer churn?") required a specific algorithm. For each different use case, thence you need to training hundreds of "narrow AI models."

The Promise of RPT-1 is that it is trained to act like an LLM for this types of questions to be answered on tabular data types. From test, it already outperforms typical text based large language models.

The demo of auto-completing a sales order line item was shown, as an example.

This tabular prediction, LLM style, can solve several classic prediction problems, all using one pre-trained model. This is SAP leveraging its core strength in structured data to build a new class of AI. 

Teched 2_SAP RPT-1

 

 

3. The Developer Experience: Open, Agentic, and in VS Code: The loudest applause of the day was reserved for the developers experience. 

SAP is making more open it's ABAP programming language and the fine tuned model (SAP-ABAP-1) to one's own preferred Integrated development environment (IDE), include tools actively adopting Vibe coding capabilities including Cline, Windsurf and Cursor among others. 

Teched 3_Open, Agentic and in VS Code

 

 

4. The Agentic Enterprise: From Build to Management: SAP is rolling out a comprehensive strategy for Agentic AI, from shipping out-of-the-box agents (Joule Agents) to capabilities of building custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio to standardizing on rapidly adopted Agentic protocols including MCP (Model Context Protocol) and A2A (Agent to Agent Protocol).

In addition, to manage this new Agentic "workforce," the strategy connects to the Business Transformation Suite: the SAP Lean IX Agent Hub provides governance, and agent mining in SAP Signavio will trace and measure their business impact.

Teched 4_ Agentic AI

 

 

 

5. The Data Fabric Gets a boost: BDC now Connects to Snowflake: SAP is aggressively expanding its openness to the data front, adding Snowflake to the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and announcing SAP Snowflake as a native solution extension.

This is a direct response to what joint customers have been asking for. The BDC Connect program, which already includes Databricks and Google Cloud, enables "secure zero-copy sharing." This means customers can bring their SAP data products directly to their existing data platforms without costly and complex data movement. The "SAP Snowflake Extension" takes this even further, bringing Snowflake's capabilities natively into the BDC. This pragmatic, open approach is critical for making the App-Data-AI flywheel a reality in heterogeneous customer landscapes.

Teched 5 SAP Snowflake Solution Extension

 

 

6. HANA Cloud, The AI-Native Database: SAP HANA Cloud is "the database AI was looking for,": I have to say, there was a great amount of love and vibes when this was mentioned on stage about HANA. For those not fully versed on HANA's history as a new columnar DB pioneered by Hasso Platner and Vishal Sikka - this is worthy addition to it history. 

The latest upgrade to HANA is that it now has Agentic capabilities and a massive performance boost!! what a story. 

Michael Ameling‚Äôs session highlighted that HANA is no longer just a fast in-memory database; it's a multi-modal database built for the AI era. The Knowledge Graph engine is now three times faster. But the real news is the introduction of agents inside the database. New "discovery agents" will help find data objects, and "agentic memory in HANA Cloud" will allow AI agents to "persist context across long-running sessions," enabling them to learn and remember. This makes HANA the intelligent, context-aware heart of the data layer.

Teched 6_HANA Cloud

 

 

7. Beyond the Hype: 'Benchmark Engineering' for AI: Philip Herzig introduced "benchmark engineering," a new toolset in AI Foundation to move AI from "vibe checking" to a true engineering discipline.

This is one of the most practical and important announcements for developers. Everyone struggles with "prompt engineering" and model unreliability. SAP is delivering a solution. The new suite includes an "Eval service" to test use cases across models, a "Prompt optimizer" (now GA) to automatically convert and improve prompts, a "Prompt registry," and "Model fallback." This is an "all you need tool set" that finally gives developers the rigorous controls they need to build and maintain enterprise-grade AI applications.

Teched 7_ Benchmark Engineering

 

 

8. Data Products Studio - The 'How' for the Data Fabric: If "BDC Connect" is about sharing data, the new "Data Products Studio" is about creating it. This new tool within Business Data Cloud allows data teams to visually model new data products, blend SAP and non-SAP data, and govern them in a shared domain-based catalog. This is the practical "how-to" for building the data fabric, giving teams the control to create the reusable, AI-ready data products that the rest of the new agentic platform will consume.

Teched 8_SAP Data Product Studio

 

9. Physical AI: Joule Agents Get Embodied: in a "one more thing" moment, Philip Herzig demonstrated the next frontier: bringing Joule Agents into the physical world through partnerships with robotics companies.

By using the new agentic protocols, Joule agents can now orchestrate physical robots. The demo showed a Joule agent delegating a warehouse picking task in EWM to a humanoid robot, which then identified a defective item and, with Joule's help, resolved the issue according to the business process. 

Teched 9_Physical AI

 

10. The Quantum Leap: SAP Primes for the Next Compute Era: While still on the horizon, SAP announced it is making huge leaps in quantum computing, focusing on algorithms and business processes rather than building the hardware. 

The vision is a "hybrid cloud architecture" where an SAP business process can "offload an intractable optimization problem to a quantum computer via a seamless API call."

The demo of a truck loading scenario showed how quantum can be "interwoven" into a business process, making it "as simple as flipping a switch" for the end-user. SAP is ensuring it will be ready to embed this power into the enterprise stack as soon as it's viable.

Teched 10_The Quantum Leap

entry.title: Automatic Supplier Specific Wording for Purchase Orders
entry.content:
How can we implement automatic wording on purchase orders that is specific to the supplier that the purchase order is for?
For example, all purchase orders standardly are sent out and in the email template, we reference our generic purchase order T/C's. 

We have a supplier in which special T/C's have been agreed upon, therefore the standard T/C's do not apply. We need to be able to reference the special T/C's either in the email template or on the purchase order only for purchase orders for this supplier. 


Is this possible and how?

entry.title: Re: How to map G/L account to Cost Center as mandatory Co...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Following the below steps to maintain the settings for account assignment type CC - Cost Center:

  1. Go to the Business Configuration work center.
  2. Go to Overview.
  3. Search for the activity Mandatory Account Assignments.
  4. Click Edit Mandatory Account Assignments for G/L Accounts.
  5. Select the respective Chart of Accounts.
  6. Filter for G/L account ABC and select the Account Assignment Type is CC - Cost Center.
    (ABC means the G/L Account number)

Best Regards,

SAP Technical Support
