entry.title: Doubt for optimize abap code in BADI
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I need to create a relationship between a position and another object in infotype HRP1001.
Currently, I am implementing a BAdI and receiving the parameter is_ee_org_ass_repl_req.

Within the implementation, I am executing several SELECT statements inside a LOOP AT to build the required structure. However, this approach is causing performance issues due to multiple database queries.

LOOP AT is_ee_org_ass_repl_req-org_assignment INTO ls_org_assignment.
        IF   iv_posicion IS NOT INITIAL.
      SELECT SINGLE sobid  FROM hrp1001 CLIENT SPECIFIED  
        INTO (@DATA(lv_sobid) )
        WHERE  mandt = @SY-mandt and plvar =  '01' and
        objid = @iv_posicion AND ( begda <= @iv_fecha AND endda >= @LV_fechaf ) AND subty = 'A012'

      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        DATA lv_sobidp TYPE plans .
        lv_sobidp = lv_sobid.
        SELECT SINGLE sobid  FROM hrp1001 
           INTO (@lv_sobid)
           WHERE objid = @LV_sobidp AND ( begda <= @iv_fecha AND endda >= @LV_fechaf ) AND otype = 'O' AND sclas = 'O'  AND subty = 'A002'.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          lv_orgeh2 = lv_sobid.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE.
lv_orgeh2 = iv_depart.
      ENDIF.    
   CALL FUNCTION 'RH_STRUC_GET' "#EC "#EC CI_SUBRC
        EXPORTING
          act_otype      = 'O'
          act_objid      = lv_orgeh2
          act_wegid      = 'BOSSONLY' 
          act_begda      = iv_fecha
          act_endda      = iv_fechaf
        TABLES
          result_tab     = lt_result_tab
        EXCEPTIONS
          no_plvar_found = 1
          no_entry_found = 2
          OTHERS         = 3.

      READ TABLE lt_result_tab INTO ls_result_tab WITH KEY otype = 'P'. 
*More code..

ENDLOOP

How can I avoid executing queries inside a LOOP AT, which is causing performance issues?

Regards

entry.title: Central Hub for Japan Tax in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Below are the key materials that you can explore to get a complete understanding of how Japan VAT will be handled in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

Featured Blog

A clear primer on the legal changes underpinning Japan‚Äôs Invoice Method and how it impacts tax accounting, invoicing, and reporting processes. It explains qualified invoice requirements, taxable vs. non-taxable treatment nuances, and the transition timeline, setting the stage for how SAP S/4HANA Cloud supports the reform.

Introduction to Invoice Method - Japan TAX Reform effective on October 1st 2023

After understanding the context of this legal requirement change, if you want to understand how this impact on S/4HANA Cloud System, please check:

3223860 - Japan - HEISEI 28 (FY 2016) Tax Reform - Introduction of Invoice Method (TEKIKAKU SEIKYUSH...: Explains scope, legal background, and solution coverage for the Invoice Method, including enablement guidance and impact on tax processing.

3067001 - Japan - HEISEI 28 (FY 2016) Tax Reform - Introduction of Invoice Method (TEKIKAKU SEIKYUSH....: Provides supporting details, corrections, and/or implementation clarifications complementing the core reform enablement.

Featured SAP Notes

  • 3006468 - Japan: Documentation on Japan VAT Return (SAP Document and Reporting Compliance): Central documentation entry for the Japan VAT return in SAP DRC.
  • 3351929 - Business Partner Extensions for Japan VAT - SAP for Me: Details Business Partner enhancements required for Japan VAT (e.g., registration numbers), including how to manage and validate them.
  • 3581293 - New tax codes for Japan not available: Troubleshooting guide for missing Japan tax codes.
  • 3578281 - Remarks field in Japan Withholding Tax White Returns: Clarifies behavior of the ‚ÄúRemarks‚Äù field in Japanese WHT white returns and guides expected data and formatting.
  • 3597702 - Error message ID_FIAA_JP_TAX074 - 'Entry for declaration key &1 and city code &2 is missing' when open Prepare Property Tax Declaration - Japan app - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Fixes ‚ÄúEntry for declaration key &1 and city code &2 is missing‚Äù by guiding through prerequisite data and configuration to avoid the error.
  • 3673084 - Net book value is zero for depreciation area 01 instead of 1 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public edition: Explains why NBV might post to an unexpected area and how to correct configuration or data dependencies that lead to zero NBV in area 01.
  • 3616097 - Why Base Value is Zero, Depreciation Amount is Non-zero in Tax Area?: Resolution for depreciation shortage.

For Japan Tax Calculation Rounding, please review:

  • 80977 - Tax calc. from gross amounts, tax rounding - part 1
  • 84356 - Tax calc. from gross amounts, several lines:part 2
  • 3291943 - 'Difference Amount' in 'Tax Reconciliation Account Balance' App Caused by Rounding
  • 3662134 - Specific Rounding rule for Japan Tax Calculation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

QnA

  • How to adjust the tax amount for Japanese yen sal... - SAP Community
  • Solved: FY23 Japan consumption tax filling obligation - SAP Community

For additional information, please review

  • Help Portal Consumption Tax | Japan.
  • Follow Tag: "japan" in "Products and Technology" - SAP Community

Stay Updated

This blog will be continually updated with the latest posts related to this topic. By following this post, you‚Äôll receive alerts whenever new material becomes available.

If you have any ideas or topics you‚Äôd like us to discuss, please share them in the comments section below.

entry.title: Bridging SAP Commerce and SAP Finance - Enabling Online Invoice Payments in SAP B2B Self Service
entry.content:
The B2B Payment Challenge

In most B2B business operations today, the final mile of the order-to-cash process which is a invoice payment and reconciliation process remains largely manual and fragmented.

Customers receive invoices, process payments through various channels for ex: bank transfers, and business finance teams spend hours matching payments with open items in SAP ERP System.

The recent B2B payment trend studies show that nearly 50% of the B2B Invoices are paid late impacting working capital and liquidity. Even when organizations have digitized their business processes, the invoice payment and reconciliation journey often remains disconnected from the digital experience.

This is exactly where the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) brings value - by connecting the self-service payment experience in the SAP B2B Portal with automatic reconciliation in SAP S/4HANA, closing the loop from Invoice to cash.

Technical Deep Dive

This blog will be discussed more on how the Integration works with a Solution Architecture that connects SAP B2B Self Service Portal, SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) and SAP S/4HANA Cloud. 

 

 

The above high-level system architecture diagram gives us the better understanding of underlying system components and its associated Integrations with other systems 

SAP Digital Payment Addon offers variety of options to choose from that includes Payment Page (3DS), Direct App Connections and Payment by link. For the purpose of Illustration of the Implementation in this blog we have considered Payment Page(3DS) as preferable mode of implementation. 

Certain Implementation hints to be known before we proceed.

  • Please note that SAP Commerce Cloud Standard Extensions does support integration with SAP digital payment add-on but the payments are related to Cart Payments and captured against Orders but not Invoices. 
  • Try to leverage OOTB SAP Commerce cloud Extension related to SAP Digital Payments and extend it for usage of Invoice Payments. These extensions has ready to use that can reduce implementation efforts.
  • Follow the Administration Guide and User Guide to setup the SAP DPA Account setup and also the preferred PSP you have decided to be onboarded. 
  • (Disclaimer) All solution screens, configurations, and integration flows shown in this article are based on a demo environment and used for illustrative purposes only.

Now Let‚Äôs break down the flow step-by-step.

Step 1: Invoice Discovery

In the B2B Self-Service Portal (SAP Commerce Cloud), customers can view their open invoices. 

  • Invoice data is fetched in real time from S/4HANA using Standard OData services or pre-built CPI iFlows.Since B2B self service portal is a Non-Transactional System, we should prefer to use OData API services to retrieve Invoice related data.

  • The portal displays key details: invoice number, date, due amount, and status.

     

Step 2: Payment Initiation

The customer selects one or more invoices and chooses to pay the same.

  • Commerce triggers a payment request to the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) using the DPA API layer. The list of API for implementation can be found here . The Sequence diagram below gives more details on the flow. 

  • DPA handles communication with the Payment Service Provider (PSP) ‚Äî e.g., Stripe, Adyen, or Worldpay ‚Äî using secure, tokenized transactions.

     

     

  • Step 3: Authorization and Capture

    Once the PSP authorizes the transaction, DPA generates a payment token and transaction reference, returning it to Commerce.

    • Commerce updates the invoice status to ‚ÄúPayment in Progress.‚Äù and Open Invoices are immediately blocked on Portal from duplication of payments. 

    • No sensitive payment data ever touches Commerce or S/4HANA ‚Äî DPA abstracts all PCI DSS compliance requirements.

    • During your implementation make sure the reference number/Invoice Id should always match with the actual Invoice ID. This will be used during Automatic Invoice Reconciliation process in S/4HANA after fetching Digital Payment Advices from PSPs.

       

  • Step 4: Posting and Reconciliation in S/4HANA

There are certain pre-requisites to be performed in SAP S/4HANA before processing Payment Advices. Managing on Virtual Bank account and setting Merchant Id Aliases are the most important aspects of this process. Please refer to the Handling Merchants Using the SAP Digital Payments which helps in performing the configurations in S/4HANA.

Reference of creating sample Virtual bank 

 

Once the payment is authorized and captured by the Payment Service Provider, the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) sends a payment advice message to SAP S/4HANA. Payment Advices are made available in DPA based on PSPs payment settlement timings. With the help of Setting Up Digital Payment Advice Processing , advices are stored in DPA and made it available to S/4HANA system during processing of Advice Processing job in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 

The flow typically follows the below path. 

Payment Advice Creation 

DPA generates a payment advice XML message containing key fields such as transaction ID, amount, currency, PSP reference, customer ID, and invoice reference. This advice is transmitted to S/4HANA via Advice Processing job in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

As discussed above in Step 3, the Invoice reference Id now plays a crucial role in determining the Open Invoice by the Auto Invoice Reconciliation process of S/4 HANA cloud. 

Below Screen is from DPA what help schedule the Job for Advice creation. Advice creations will PSP specific.

below is the screen shot of S/4 HANA cloud that shows us the reference of Job Execution for Auto Reconciliation. make sure select the right bank key, payment Method, Merchant Alias and PSP. 

Automatic Clearing:

When matching criteria are met (invoice number, customer account, payment amount), the system executes automatic clearing using standard FI-AR logic.

If partial or unmatched items exist, they remain in the payment advice queue for manual review.

once the job is successful, as the below reference screen shot we will see the success message . 

  • Step 5: Real-Time Status Visibility

Customers can immediately see that their invoice has been ‚ÄúPaid and Cleared‚Äù ‚Äî and Finance can view the same in the AR aging report, ensuring complete alignment between customer-facing and backend systems.

Technical Components:

Layer SAP Component Role

PresentationSAP B2B Self ServiceB2B Self-Service Portal with invoice display and payment initiation
IntegrationPoint - PointOrchestration between Commerce, DPA, and S/4HANA
Payment GatewaySAP Digital Payments Add-OnSecure payment hub for PSP communication
Core ERPSAP S/4HANA Public or PCEPosting, clearing, and reconciliation of customer payments

Conclusion 

In the B2B world, digital transformation is not complete until payments are automated. By connecting SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Digital Payments Add-On, and SAP S/4HANA, businesses can finally close the loop - achieving a true ‚ÄúClick-to-Cash‚Äù experience.

It‚Äôs not just about collecting payments faster - it‚Äôs about aligning customer convenience, financial accuracy, and process intelligence in one integrated flow.

entry.title: Source Data Extraction for SAP Signavio Process Intelligence using SAP Datasphere Replication Flows
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere has recently introduced the new connection type "SAP Signavio," enabling Replication Flows to replicate data directly to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence. This allows CDS Views and ABAP tables from SAP ERP systems to be replicated in a manner similar to any other replication use case in Datasphere.

On the SAP Signavio Process Intelligence side, the data will be pushed by the replication flow into the object store of the customer's Signavio workspace. A replication flow can then be mapped to a source data, providing the data from the corresponding ABAP tables and CDS Views to the Signavio ETL Pipeline to generate the process mining event log.

High-Level component overview

The diagram illustrates the complete data flow:

  • Left: Source systems (S/4HANA Public Cloud for CDS Views; S/4HANA/ECC with SLT for ABAP tables)
  • Center: SAP Datasphere orchestrates the replication flow
  • Right: SAP Signavio Process Intelligence receives data as Source Data objects
  • The dashed vertical line represents the boundary between customer landscape and internet connectivity via SAP Cloud Connector

We demonstrate now how to create a replication flow for:
(a) the customer object (CDS View i_customer) in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.
(b) the sales order object (ABAP tables VBAK and VBAP) in S/4HANA or SAP ECC 

Prerequisite:

  • We have a user and space in the SAP Datasphere service on BTP and have the authorization to create a new connection and to create and execute replication flows. Note that we use Replication in the pass-through option and don't require a SAP HANA as staging area within SAP Datasphere (see Replication Flow Blog series).
    We have noted down the Datasphere Tenant ID (System => About => Tenant).
  • For the replication of CDS views we have configured the integration scenario SAP_COM_0532 in our S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (see blog S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration with SAP Dataspehere )
  • For the replication of ABAP tables we have configured the SAP Landscape Transformation component (SLT) in our S/4HANA on-premise or use a standalone SLT system connected to our S/4 HANA system. We have enabled connectivity to the ABAP landscape via SAP Cloud Connector to SAP Datasphere (see Replicating table data from an SAP ECC system with SAP Datasphere using Replication Flows)
  • In SAP Signavio we have access to a workspace subscribed to Process Intelligence and have the authorization to perform Process Data Pipeline steps

Connectivity Handshake Signavio <-> Datasphere:

To establish a secure connection between SAP Datasphere and SAP Signavio, an OAuth Flow is required.  To do so, we start with creating an OAuth Client in our Datasphere tenant. Navigate to System => Administration and choose tab App Integration. When clicking on "Add an OAuth Client" you create your OAuth Client for Signavio. Give it a name, choose the purpose "Technical User", enter a name for the technical user to be created and assign the appropriate roles (refer to the documentation to assign the requires scoped integrator role).

Once the system has created the OAuth Client, it provides you with the OAuth credentials. Make sure to copy the credentials and note it down, you need it in the next step.

We now switch to Signavio and use the created OAuth Client to establish a secure connection. Create a "SAP Datasphere Replication Flow" connection in Signavio Process Intelligence. There is also a "SAP Datasphere" connection which relates to read the data from the SAP HANA instance in SAP Datasphere. Mind, this is not the integration flow we are looking into here and make sure to select the one with replication flow.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

In the next screen we enter the OAuth Client Credentials we have noted down earlier:

  • OAuth Client ID: Client ID you have noted down in the previous step
  • OAuth Client Secret: secret you have noted down in the previous step
  • Service Root: URL root of the Datasphere App Integration page where you create the OAuth client
  • OAuth Access Token URL: Token URL you find in the overview of the OAuth Clients in SAP Datasphere (ends with /oauth/token)

After we have created the connection in Signavio we have now established the OAuth connectivity handshake between Signavio and Datasphere and can work on a secure connection.

Let's now create the corresponding Signavio connection in Datasphere.

We logon to our SAP Datasphere instance and select our space where we create the connections and replication flows.
In the left bar menu we choose Connections and create a new connection of type Signavio. 

In the following screen we enter the connection URL of the respective Signavio landscape. In our case it is EU which is the URL https://api-mtls.eu.signavio.cloud.sap. You find the right API-Gateway endpoints in the SAP Signavio documentation for regions, IP addresses and URLs.

After entering a name for the connection we can save and validate the connection:

The Datasphere tenant is automatically mapped to the corresponding Signavio connection where we had entered the respective Datasphere tenant ID. We can not map this Datasphere tenant to another Signavio workspace unless we delete the connection in Signavio.

Replicate customer information (CDS View i_customer)

After establishing the Signavio connection we create a connection to the SAP S/4 HANA system to replicate the CDS View i_customer. We create a new connection of type S/4HANA Public Cloud:

 

We use certificate or user/password from the Communication Arrangement for Communication Scenario 0532.

Once created and validated we can continue to configure our Replication Flow for the CDS View i_customer. Choose Data Builder and new Replication Flow:

We perform the following steps to configure the source of Replication Flow:

  1. Select your S/4HANA Public Cloud as source connection
  2. Choose CDS View Extraction as source container
  3. Select CDS View I_CUSTOMER 

We configure now:

  • Load Type: Initial and Delta
  • Our recently created Signavio Connection as target
  • Content-Type "Template Type" to allow ABAP Types transformation such as Date/Time in Signavio
  • the name of the Replication Flow

Once we have saved and deployed the Replication Flow we run it. In the Integration monitor we check the status of the replication:

Once initial load is finished the delta handling will regularly replicate the changes to Signavio.

Let's now switch back to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence and create a corresponding source data. 
We crate a new source data for our new replication flow RF_Customer and assign the earlier created connection to it.

Once created we can sync the data which results in processing the data provided by the replication flow from SAP Datasphere. In particular, the initial load and possible deltas will be merged and we get the replica of the ABAP source data in Signavio. It may take some minutes depending on the size of the CDS views.

Mind, that whenever the Replication Flows send delta information a new sync is required to update the source data.

To validate the replication or use the data we have to create a Process Data Pipeline and create a SQL script. We create a new Process Data Pipeline based on a blank template and choose our source data RF_Customer.

We create a new Process Data Model with business object Customer and open the SQL Editor for a new event collector.

We can now use the preview option to validate the extraction, e.g. showing Top100 entries, count the replicated entities, etc. 

Replicate sales order information (ABAP tables VBAK and VBAP)
In the previous chapter we have successfully replicated the data from a CDS View. If we have an ABAP table to be replicated we have to leverage the SAP Landscape Transformation Server (SLT) integration to Datasphere.

Assuming we have our SLT component configured in our ABAP system (or use a dedicated SLT server) we can create a new mass transfer ID in SLT. We create it using transaction code ltrc.

Click on Create Configuration and enter the following information in the subsequent screens:

  • Configuration Name and Description
  • RFC Destination and (optionally) Read from Single Client flag
  • SAP Data Intelligence (Replication Management Service) under Other in Target System
  • Job options (we may start with 1 job first)

We have finished our SLT preparation step. All following replication configurations (tables, fields, filters, etc.) will now be configured in the Replication Flow in Datasphere which will be then pushed down to your SLT configuration. Let's switch to our Datasphere tenant and create a new connection to our SLT instance. 

When creating a new connection choose SAP ABAP as system type:

  • Protocol: RFC
  • Connection Type: Application Server (or Message Server if you prefer)
  • Application Server, System Number and Client
  • Choose Cloud Connector to allow on-premise connectivity
  • Authentication Type: for user/password choose your ABAP user for SLT with appropriate roles

We can save and validate our new connection.

 

Once connection is established, we create a new Replication Flow for our ABAP table replication. Create the replication flow similar to the CDS View, but use SLT as source container:

  • Business Name: RF_SalesOrder
  • Source Connection: our SLT connection
  • Source Container: "SLT - SAP LT Replication Server"
    • our mass transfer ID from the ABAP system
  • Source Objects: ABAP Tables VBAK and VBAP 
  • Load Type: Initial and Delta
  • Content Type: Template Type
  • (optional): add a projection to filter the data or reduce the number of fields
  • Target Connection: your Signavio connection (same as used for CDS View replication)

Optionally you may add filters or field projections which will be pushed down to SLT and reduces the data volume to be transferred.

Save, Deploy and run the replication flow. To monitor the transfer you can choose Data Integration Monitor in Datasphere and the monitoring tool in SLT. Data will be gathered by SLT and Datasphere can then pull the data to Datasphere and directly forward it to Signavio.

You see the replication status of each table and some metrics on the replication run, e.g. 886.757 entries from VBAK had bee initially replicated in 5:12 minutes using 9 partitions, 3 delta updates have been already executed.

Once data is replicated the Replication flow will show status "Active (retrying objects)" as we have chosen Initial and Delta Mode. The Replication Flow continuously checks for updates in the ABAP Tables and replicate them to Signavio.

Let's switch to Signavio and create a corresponding source data for our replication flow for the sales order ABAP Table.

We have selected the same Datasphere connection as we have used for the CDS Views, and the RF_SalesOrder replication flow.

In the following screen we sync the replication flow. 

Once the sync is being processed we can see the tables VBAK and VBAP alongside with the sync log.

 

With having the source data prepared for further processing we can now create a Process Data Pipeline to generate the process mining event log.

In our pipeline we crate a new business object SalesOrder and create the SQL scripts for case and event collectors. As an example we create the event collector "create sales order".

We've demonstrated how to leverage SAP Datasphere to replicate and synchronize data from source systems using Replication Flow. Give this method a try and share your results and experiences in the comments below!

entry.title: New Kyma Telemetry Docs: Simplified, Task-Oriented, and User-First
entry.content:
We're happy to announce the release of the completely restructured and rewritten documentation for the Kyma Telemetry module! We've moved from a component-centric view to a user-first, task-oriented structure, all centered around a new, unified Telemetry Pipeline API.

 

What's New for Our Users?

  • The Unified Telemetry Pipeline API ‚Äì At the heart of the new structure is the Telemetry Pipeline API. With the introduction of OTLP-based LogPipelines, you can now use a consistent set of CRDs to configure all your telemetry signals, which reduces complexity and makes your setup easier to maintain.

  • A Clearer, Task-Based Structure ‚Äì Find what you need faster with new top-level guides for Collecting Logs, Collecting Traces, and Collecting Metrics. Each guide walks you through the process for a specific signal, from minimal setup to advanced configuration

  • A Clear Migration Path ‚Äì If you're still using the legacy Fluent Bit (HTTP) log output, read Migrate Your LogPipeline From HTTP to OTLP, which guides you step-by-step to switch to the new OTLP setup without data loss.

The 'Why' Behind the Change: A Look at the Craft

If you're a fellow tech writer or just curious about the why, this wasn't just a rewrite; it was a fundamental shift in our information architecture:

Our previous documentation was component-centric. It described each component (Telemetry Manager, gateways, agents, pipelines...) and its internal architecture, explaining "What does the component do?". Based on that, the reader had to figure out how to accomplish a task.

Our new approach is goal-oriented, built on principles from the DITA (Darwin Information Typing Architecture) and industry best practices. Our guiding question is "What is the user trying to achieve?" This led us to structure the content as self-contained pages, each focusing on a user goal. For readers interested in the nitty-gritty details - you still find all of those in the consolidated Architecture docs.

Why This Matters

This new structure makes it easier to see what's common and what's different for the Telemetry pipeline types. Furthermore, we've re-centered the documentation on the actions you need to perform:

  • Start with your goal: Task-oriented titles such as Monitor Pipeline Health help you find what you need without knowing our internal component names.
  • Progressive disclosure of information: Get started with a minimal configuration quickly, and then explore advanced operations like filtering or processing only when you need them.
  • Get straight to the point: With consolidated troubleshooting instructions on the top level, you can start start fixing issues immediately without reading through unrelated details.

Get Started Today

We invite you to dive into the new Telemetry module documentation. We're proud of this new structure and believe it's a clear step up for clarity and usability.

Your Feedback Matters

Whether you're a user of the module or a fellow writer, we'd love to hear your thoughts. Give us feedback directly on the SAP Help Portal pages. Your input is crucial as we continue to evolve our content.

entry.title: Re: Location mapping in Recruiting Marketing
entry.content:
Hi @Nim_18 ,

When you use the Location Object on the Job Requisition, the Location field stores an object reference (Location GUID), not the display name.
Even though you see the ‚ÄúName‚Äù in the Recruiting UI, RMK feeds don‚Äôt automatically resolve it to the display name unless that specific location field is mapped as a string field in CSB > Job Field Mapping.

Solution : Use a Custom String Field

  1. Create a custom field in the Job Requisition (e.g.,customLocationName)

  2. Make it a standard string field type.

  3. Add a Business Rule that auto-populates this custom field with the Location.name whenever the req is created.

Rule Sample
Event: On Save
IF: Location is not empty
THEN: Set customLocationName=Location.name

  1. Map customLocationName to the feed field in

Hope this helps!! Let me know if you need any help

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

entry.title: Re: How to delete SAP Cloud ALM?
entry.content:
Hello Customer,

To delete the requested Cloud ALM tenant, you can firstly delete the subscription and then delete the subaccount.
Steps are outlined in the KBA:

3352417 - Dismantle and then Resubscribe SAP Cloud ALM in different Data Center
3247776 - How to Unsubscribe the Subscription for SAP Cloud ALM in the SAP Cloud ALM Subaccount

If there is a request to delete the Global Account as well, please reach out to your SAP Account Executive as outlined in KBA 3249196.

Best regards,
Ellie

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP BTP Cloud Logging Service with SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) Using SAML
entry.content:
Introduction

  • Why this matters: SAP Cloud Logging (based on OpenSearch) supports SAML 2.0 integration for secure access and role-based authorization using IAS Groups.
  • Benefits:
    • Centralized identity management
    • Single Sign-On (SSO)
    • Compliance with SAP BTP security recommendations (BTP-CLS-0001)
  • Prerequisites:
    • A Cloud Logging Service instance in SAP BTP
    • An active SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) tenant

Step 1: Prepare IAS for SAML Integration

  1. Log in to IAS Admin Console: https://[tenant].accounts.ondemand.com/admin
  2. Create a new SAML 2.0 Application:
    • Application Name: CloudLogging-CLS-Test

  3. Add SAML 2.0 Configuration:
    • Configure Manually

    • SP Entity ID: cls-test
    • ACS URL: https://[cls-url]/_opendistro/_security/saml/acs
      (Please get this ACS URL from CLS instance "dashboards-endpoint")
    • Single Logout URL: https://[cls-url]
    • Binding: HTTP_REDIRECT

    • NameID Format: Email

  4. Configure Attributes:
    • Name: groups
    • Source: Identity Directory
    • Value: All Groups

Step 2: Create IAS Group for Admin Access

  • Group Name: LoggingAdmins
  • Assign users who need administrative access to Cloud Logging.

Step 3: Generate Signing Key and Certificate (Optional)

You can skip this step. If you enable signed authentication requests in IAS:

openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout private.key -out cert.pem -nodes -days 365
openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -v1 PBE-SHA1-3DES -in private.key -out private_pkcs8.key
base64 -w0 private_pkcs8.key > private_pkcs8.b64
  • Upload cert.pem to IAS.
  • Use the Base64-encoded private key in Cloud Logging configuration.

Step 4: Configure Cloud Logging Service

Create a JSON file (saml-config.jsonüòû

{
  "saml": {
    "enabled": true,
    "initiated": true,
    "idp": {
      "metadata_url": "https://<IAS-tenant>/saml2/metadata",
      "entity_id": "https://<IAS-tenant>"
    },
    "admin_group": "LoggingAdmins",
    "roles_key": "groups",
    "sp": {
      "entity_id": "cls-test",
      "signature_private_key": "<Base64-encoded-key>",
      "signature_private_key_password": "<password>"
    },
    "exchange_key": "RandomKey32CharsRandomKey32Chars"
  }
}

Apply the configuration:

cf update-service cls-test -c saml-config.json

Step 5: Validate the Integration

  • Open the Cloud Logging Dashboard URL: https://[your-cls-url]
  • Confirm redirection to IAS login.
  • Log in with a user from LoggingAdmins group.
  • Verify OpenSearch roles (all_access) are mapped correctly.

Troubleshooting

  • 400 Bad Request: Check ACS URL and SP Entity ID match IAS settings.
  • 401 Unauthorized: Verify group attribute mapping and signature settings.
  • Disable SAML if needed:
cf update-service cls-test -c '{"saml":{"enabled":false}}'

Conclusion

  • SAML integration ensures secure, centralized authentication for Cloud Logging.
  • IAS provides flexibility for role-based access and SSO.
  • Always use strong passwords and manage certificates securely.

entry.title: Re: Unplanned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
entry.content:
@nithin_pranesh thanks for the detailed explanation. first of all, i dont think two different PO will achieve your goal. So let's focus on your workaround. I think you can use Subsequent Debit instead of the unplanned delivery cost in the header level.

Step 1:  you can follow the step " Post Supplier Invoice Verification" in Planned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S/4HANA Clo... - SAP Community  to post both goods items and planned delivery items. 

Step 2: You can use Subsequent Debit to post unplanned delivery costs which can also be tracked in PO history. follow the steps  Scenario 2, Option 2 in this blog.

At I tested, looks like it matches your requirement.

100 CNY for goods items

5 CNY for planned delivery cost

2 CNY for differences between actual delivery and planned delivery. and it has been posted to inventory account.
